sultan

  1. a Muslim ruler
  2. [S-] the former monarch of Turkey

Origin of sultan

French from Arabic sul??n, ruler, prince, origin, originally , dominion

sultan

noun

  1. A ruler of a Muslim country, especially of the former Ottoman Empire.
  2. A powerful person: a sultan of vice and corruption.

Origin of sultan

French from Old French ruler of Turkey from Turkish from Arabic sul&tlowdot;ān from Aramaic šul&tlowdot;ānā ruler from šəla&tlowdot; to rule šl&tlowdot;

(plural sultans)

  1. Originally, a secular Link: /secular office, formally subordinate to -, but de facto the power behind the throne of the (theoretically universal) caliph Link: /caliph .
  2. A hereditary ruler Link: /ruler in various Muslim Link: /Muslim states Link: /states (sultanate), varying from petty principalities (as in Indonesia and in Yemen), often vassal of a greater ruler, to independent realms, such as Oman Link: /Oman , Brunei Link: /Brunei , or an empire such as the Turkish Ottoman Empire.
  3. (card games) A variant of solitaire Link: /solitaire , played with two decks of cards.
  4. A breed Link: /breed of chicken Link: /chicken originating in Turkey, kept primarily in gardens for ornamental reasons. See: sultan (chicken)

From French Link: /French sultan, from Turkish Link: /Turkish sultan, from Arabic Link: /Arabic Ø³ÙÙ„Ù’Ø·ÙŽØ§Ù†ÙŒ (sulá¹­Än), from Aramaic Link: /Aramaic ×©×•×œ×˜× × (Å¡ulá¹­ÄnÄ, “strength, authority") (compare Hebrew ×©Ö´××œÖ°×˜×•Ö¹×Ÿ (shiltÃ³n)). Compare soldan Link: /soldan .
